title: Certified upcycled foods continue to gain traction with the category projected to reach $80b by 2032 - FoodNavigator-USA.com
summary: The Upcycled Trade Association, founded in 2019, has expanded from nine to 260 companies, projecting growth to $80 billion by 2032. Its CEO attributes this growth to a clear definition of upcycled food and a certification program that helps prevent greenwashing and consumer skepticism. The certification assures consumers and promotes awareness of upcycled food, which has increased from less than 10% to upwards of 40% among mainstream consumers. The association continues to focus on consumer education and retailer collaboration to highlight the value of upcycled foods.
green_innovation: TRUE - This is green innovation because it promotes the use of food ingredients that would otherwise be wasted, thereby reducing waste and contributing to environmental sustainability.
business_innovation: TRUE - This is a business innovation as it introduces a certification program that significantly differs from previous practices and improves the market for upcycled food products.
green_product: TRUE - The upcycled food products fit the definition of a green product as they are designed to reduce environmental impact by utilizing ingredients that would have otherwise been wasted.
green_process: TRUE - The process of upcycling food through a verified supply chain minimizes waste and promotes sustainability in production.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311 - Food Manufacturing, 3119 - Other Food Manufacturing, 722 - Food Services and Drinking Places, 541 - Professional, Scientific, and Technical Services
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not suggest any misleading claims about environmental benefits; instead, it emphasizes the clear definitions and third-party certification that protect against greenwashing.

title: Upcycled flour replacement introduced at IFT FIRST - BakingBusiness.com
summary: Renewal Mill has introduced a 100% upcycled flour replacement blend called RenewALL, which can be used as a substitute for conventional flour in various recipes. The blend offers more fiber and protein than whole wheat flour while being neutral in flavor and supportive of upcycled ingredient use. R&D chef Alice Medrich described the product as revolutionary for shortening development timelines and promoting more upcycled products in the market.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the product is made from 100% upcycled ingredients and contributes to sustainability by reducing waste and promoting the use of renewable resources.
business_innovation: TRUE, it represents a new and improved product that is significantly different from previous offerings in the market and has been introduced for commercial use.
green_product: TRUE, because it is designed and manufactured in a way that significantly reduces environmental impact through upcycling, improving nutritional content, and promoting sustainable practices.
green_process: FALSE, because while the product itself is green, the article does not detail any specific green processes in manufacturing or production that minimize environmental impact.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311811 - Retail Bakeries, 311612 - Meat Processed from Carcasses, 311999 - All Other Miscellaneous Food Manufacturing, 325199 - All Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE, there is no indication of misleading claims about the environmental benefits of the product; it appears to genuinely promote sustainability.

title: Food product quality, environmental and personal characteristics affecting consumer perception toward food - Frontiers
summary: The article discusses the evolving food industry, highlighting innovations in product categories driven by consumer perceptions and the need for sustainable practices. It emphasizes how factors such as sensory attributes, regional variations, and consumer health influence food acceptance and purchasing decisions. Furthermore, the article explores the challenges and opportunities presented by new food technologies and consumer attitudes toward them, particularly regarding plant-based and upcycled foods.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the article discusses innovations in the food industry that focus on sustainability, including the development of plant-based foods and upcycled products, which aim to reduce environmental impacts.
business_innovation: TRUE, because the article describes the emergence of new product categories and processing technologies that significantly differ from previous offerings in the food industry.
green_product: TRUE, because the article mentions plant-based foods and upcycled food products, which are designed to reduce environmental impacts and promote sustainability.
green_process: TRUE, because the article discusses innovative processing technologies that enhance sustainability and minimize negative environmental impacts, such as the use of upcycled ingredients.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 311811 - Retail Bakeries; 311999 - All Other Food Manufacturing; 311513 - Cheese Manufacturing; 311520 - Ice Cream and Frozen Dessert Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE, because the article does not suggest that companies are making misleading claims about the environmental benefits of their products; rather, it focuses on genuine innovations aimed at sustainability.
